acceptedAnswer.text: BMI (Body Mass Index) is a measurement that uses your height and weight to determine if your weight is healthy. It's calculated by dividing your weight in kilograms by your height in meters squared (kg/m²). BMI is used by healthcare professionals worldwide to identify potential weight-related health risks.

BMI is calculated using the formula: BMI = weight (kg) ÷ [height (m)]². For example, if you weigh 70 kg and are 1.75 m tall, your BMI would be 70 ÷ (1.75 × 1.75) = 22.9. Our free BMI calculator automatically converts between different units and performs this calculation instantly.

mainEntity.name: What is a healthy BMI range?

acceptedAnswer.text: According to the World Health Organization (WHO), BMI categories are: Underweight (BMI below 18.5), Normal weight (BMI 18.5-24.9), Overweight (BMI 25.0-29.9), and Obese (BMI 30.0 and above). A BMI between 18.5 and 24.9 is generally considered healthy for most adults.

BMI is a useful screening tool but has limitations. It doesn't distinguish between muscle and fat mass, so very muscular people may have a high BMI despite being healthy. It also doesn't account for age, gender, bone density, or body composition. Always consult a healthcare professional for personalized health assessment.
